body.title: People are 'demanding answers' after man is knocked out by 'UFO' in shocking video
body.description: People are 'demanding answers' after home CCTV footage shows a man getting knocked out by a 'weird object'. Believers think ...
body.article_content:
People are 'demanding answers' after home CCTV footage shows a man getting knocked out by a 'weird object'.

Believers think it's a 'UFO', while others have come up with even crazier theories.

Have a look to see what you think:

A few months ago, a Reddit user shared a mind-boggling video on the platform, and it's certainly divided the crowd.

Advert

The viral clip, filmed on 21 July, appears to show a man being knocked over outside of a home shortly after entering the property.

This happens 14 seconds into the video, as an object that appears out of nowhere slams into the door frame.

Friends or family then head outside to check on the individual who fell over.

Some think this viral Reddit video shows a 'UFO' knocking out a man 'in Columbia' (Reddit/u/kamm03)

Advert

"So this happened a few days ago in my hometown in Colombia," the user claimed.

"A really fast and strange object knocked a man down to the floor thru the stairs.

"He had 24 stitches at the hospital.

"I wouldn't classify this as an orb as some my friends think neither an animal, what do you guys think?"

Advert

As you'd expect, people in the comments were coming up with all sorts of theories, as one person said: "This video is absolutely wild.

It has been claimed that the incident was filmed 'in Columbia' earlier this year (Reddit/u/kamm03)

"Haven’t ever seen anything like it. Looks like there’s lots of reflection on the side of the vehicle. Not sure if that’s from traffics or what."

While another thought: "It was just something tied to the door tied tight to hold it open. If you watch the door starts to close right before it happened."

Advert

Then a third argued: "Not... really. Just actually look at the reflection and you see it actually goes on a lot longer than the 'object'.

"What likely happened here is the guy got knocked out by something from inside, or got electrocuted and jumped back.

"And at the exact same time some bug lit up in front of the camera."

The clip has divided the viewers (Reddit/u/kamm03)

Advert

Someone else also questioned: "Idk.. the fact that the dog goes immediately towards where the object came from kinda freaks me out. Right after that, the dog does move to the body on the ground but its attention is immediately taken to that area. I wonder if the dog's sniffer picked something up."

"The eagle eyes that spotted the object circling around the cement mixer help confirmed depth and motion," a fifth added. "This is a bug that is flying to the left, then towards the camera then up and over the top right edge of the camera nearly directly at it. Velocity and size of the object increase relatively proportionally to each other."

Whatever your opinion, we can surely all agree how weird it is?

body.title: Did a UFO hover over San Antonio Sunday night? Reddit chimes in
body.description: A TikTok video of a mysterious objecting hovering over San Antonio raised questions about whether it's a UFO or a plastic bag ...
body.article_content:
Digital depiction of UFO lights in the sky David Wall/Getty Images

A video making the rounds online is begging the question: Is there life out there in the cosmos, and are they taking a peek at the Alamo City? While it’s certainly not the first time someone reported seeing strange flying objects in the sky over San Antonio, it’s an unusually clear video of what folks believe to be a UFO.

A TikTok user shared a video of a mysterious rotating object hovering in the sky off North Alamo Street in Downtown San Antonio. While it appeared metallic or white in the video, the TikTok poster, Justin Delgado, says it nearly blended in with the darkest part of the sky.

When the video was shared on Reddit, several commenters noted they’ve been seeing mysterious objects in the sky more frequently as of late. Some said reports or quickly cropping up in New Mexico, Arizona and across the globe while other say they’ve seen suspicious activity in Texas.

Advertisement Article continues below this ad

“I seen it all the way from Lacoste,” Reddit user Historical_Wish_7627 commented. “I’ve been seeing lots of weird stuff in the sky lately.”

Another Reddit poster who lives in a rural area outside San Antonio reported seeing what looked like a satellite moving across the sky one night that faded into the night sky. The same poster says they saw a pair of mysterious lights, which they say wasn’t a helicopter or airplane, hovering over the Alamo City.

Others were quick to quips on the speculation of aliens visiting San Antonio. In reference to a recent video of a mattress flying down a highway in the city, having dislodged off the back of a fast-moving pickup truck, Reddit users joked the mattress had made it into airspace.

Advertisement Article continues below this ad

“The highway mattress has breached containment,” Reddit user audientix posted, with many responding with their own jokes about the mattress being the sources of the conspiracy. There were plenty of other jokes to be made on the thread without reference to a mattress, though.

“That was abuela’s chancla after whooping you so hard it was sent into orbit,” Reddit user Chiken_97 wrote.

body.title: Google’s AI podcast creator NotebookLM could be coming to the Gemini app on your phone
body.description: Delving deep into the code for the latest beta version of the Google Gemini app, it looks like Google ’s NotebookLM AI ...
body.article_content: Beta code hints that Gemini will get NotebookLM access NotebookLM will allow Gemini to create AI podcasts from PDFs or videos Linked to your mobile, AI Podcasts could help you learn about any subject around you Delving deep into the code for the latest beta version of the Google Gemini app, it looks like Google’s NotebookLM AI podcast creation software might be coming to Google Gemini on your phone. Android Authority has found the following lines of code in a beta version of Gemini: Generate audio overview Generate audio overview As you can see, both “create_podcast” and “Generate audio overview” are visible, indicating that Gemini will have the ability to generate a podcast. Moreover, the NotebookLM section that creates the podcast is called an audio overview. Taken together, these two things would seem to indicate a role for Google’s NotebookLM in a future version of Gemini. How would it work? Of all the weird and wonderful uses of AI to arrive in 2024, Google’s NotebookLM remains one of the most captivating. NotebookLM contains a number of products that use AI to help you learn any subject. You feed in your source material as a text file, PDF, or video, and it helps you organize that material. One of the ways it does this is through audio overviews. An audio overview is essentially an audio file that takes the form of a podcast show between two hosts who are discussing whatever subject you’ve fed it via PDFs, web pages, or a YouTube video. Listening to two people discuss a subject is a great way to help you learn about it. What makes NotebookLM great is how realistic the podcast sounds. It’s very hard to believe you’re not listening to two real people discussing the subject at hand. If Gemini gives you the ability to create audio podcasts from data sources you feed it, then it’s going to be a great way to help you learn about new subjects. Get the best Black Friday deals direct to your inbox, plus news, reviews, and more. Sign up to be the first to know about unmissable Black Friday deals on top tech, plus get all your favorite TechRadar content. Contact me with news and offers from other Future brands Receive email from us on behalf of our trusted partners or sponsors You can imagine the situation where you upload a PDF to Gemini and then ask it, “Hey, can you make me a podcast about this PDF?” Combine that with Google Lens, and you could be able to get Gemini to generate podcasts about things you are looking at. Just imagine taking a trip around a famous building, like the Vatican, or having Gemini produce a podcast about the building that acts as a guided tour. The potential for NotebookLM to integrate with other apps or be useful in new situations is almost unlimited, and we’d expect to see Google coming up with new and interesting ways to use it in the very near future.

body.title: How AI Is Reinforcing Healthcare Apps and Redefining Wellness
body.description: Digital transformation in the global healthcare sector has been rapid, with artificial intelligence emerging as the key ...
body.article_content:
Digital transformation in the global healthcare sector has been rapid, with artificial intelligence emerging as the key player in the frontier. AI has constantly revolutionized healthcare apps, redefining wellness and improving health outcomes. However, as with any innovation, specific practical issues and challenges, like ensuring transparency, regulatory compliance, and privacy concerns, still need to be addressed. But the advantages and advancements of AI outweigh these hurdles by offering real-time insights, predictive analytics, and personalized health management that were once unimaginable.

The top 3 ways how AI is transforming healthcare apps

AI is doing more than enhancing the functionality of healthcare apps – it is transforming the applications into a more sophisticated system that is capable of predictive analytics and providing personalized care. AI integrated into the applications can process vast amounts of data, provide actionable insights, and analyze the data for patterns. Let’s take a closer look at the capabilities:

Health Monitoring: AI-powered healthcare apps can continuously track vitals and alert users of anomalies and when have to take immediate action.

AI-powered healthcare apps can continuously track vitals and alert users of anomalies and when have to take immediate action. Predictive Analytics: Artificial Intelligence algorithms predict potential health risks based on user data, such as blood sugar levels or heart rate.

Artificial Intelligence algorithms predict potential health risks based on user data, such as blood sugar levels or heart rate. Personalized Care: Artificial Intelligence provides customized health recommendations based on users’ individual profiles, such as sleep patterns, nutrition plans, exercise routines, etc.

These technological advances provide a proactive approach to the frontier of health management, allowing users to manage their health issues before the conditions worsen.

How AI plays a crucial role in your wellness management

Artificial Intelligence is redefining wellness by focusing on a holistic approach, which includes wellbeing of emotional, physical, and mental health. With AI’s ability to analyze data from wearable and smartphones, AI health apps can deliver a unique level of personalization that was previously unseen.

Take a look at some of the basic features of AI-powered applications:

Personalized wellness plans: Artificial Intelligence creates personalized plans on sleep, fitness, and diet that are tailored to an individual’s lifestyle.

Artificial Intelligence creates personalized plans on sleep, fitness, and diet that are tailored to an individual’s lifestyle. Mental health support: AI-based wellness applications offer mental health support services, such as mood tracking, cognitive behavioral therapy, and stress management, to help users manage their mental health.

AI-based wellness applications offer mental health support services, such as mood tracking, cognitive behavioral therapy, and stress management, to help users manage their mental health. Holistic health monitoring: AI tracks and provides recommendations for all aspects of spirit, mind, and body.

A JAMA Psychiatry study in 2023 found that AI-powered therapy platforms improved users’ mental health by 55%, which underlines the scope of AI’s impact on mental health management.

AI overcoming the challenges of the healthcare industry through mobile apps

AI addresses many long-standing challenges in the healthcare industry, including inefficiencies in treatment and diagnosis discrepancies. AI-based innovations are consistently improving the accuracy and accessibility of healthcare services. Let’s have a detailed look:

Rapid diagnosis: Artificial Intelligence can process medical images and analyze patient records more accurately and rapidly than manual processing. For instance, AI can detect fractures in X-rays or even spot signs of cancer.

Artificial Intelligence can process medical images and analyze patient records more accurately and rapidly than manual processing. For instance, AI can detect fractures in X-rays or even spot signs of cancer. Online consultations: AI-based chatbots provide quick responses to health inquiries and schedule online consultations, making healthcare more convenient and accessible.

AI-based chatbots provide quick responses to health inquiries and schedule online consultations, making healthcare more convenient and accessible. Management of chronic diseases: AI-powered applications enable users to track chronic conditions by providing real-time data and suggestions for diseases like asthma, diabetes, and cardiac issues.

For instance, a study by The Lancet reveals that AI models outperform radiologists in diagnosing breast cancer from mammograms with an accuracy rate of 94.6%.

What we can expect from AI in the future of healthcare apps

The continuing evolution of AI is shaping the future of healthcare app development. The contribution of mobile application development companies in Dubai is essential in this technological evolution because they incorporate artificial intelligence into the app development process to create more efficient and innovative apps. Let’s have a quick glimpse at what we can expect to see in healthcare apps in the time ahead:

Predictive healthcare solutions: Mobile app developers are leveraging artificial intelligence to accurately predict and prevent diseases like cardio issues, pulmonary issues, and diabetes.

Mobile app developers are leveraging artificial intelligence to accurately predict and prevent diseases like cardio issues, pulmonary issues, and diabetes. Integration with wearable devices: AI in healthcare apps seamlessly integrates with wearable devices, which monitor vitals in real time for continuous care.

AI in healthcare apps seamlessly integrates with wearable devices, which monitor vitals in real time for continuous care. Enhanced user experience: Artificial Intelligence will make apps more friendly by offering them tailored recommendations and notifications based on real-time data.

AI influencing the trends of the wellness industry

From fitness to nutrition trackers, here’s how AI is driving innovation and transforming the broader wellness industry:

AI-powered fitness applications: Applications use Artificial Intelligence to recommend personalized workout plans based on the user’s current fitness levels.

Applications use Artificial Intelligence to recommend personalized workout plans based on the user’s current fitness levels. Nutrition tracking: AI users can build diet plans that are tailored to their nutritional needs, preferences, and medical conditions, even by factoring in minute details like allergies.

AI users can build diet plans that are tailored to their nutritional needs, preferences, and medical conditions, even by factoring in minute details like allergies. Mental health and mindfulness: AI-powered wellness applications offer users stress relief, emotional support, and personalized meditation.

Dubai’s app companies are gradually adopting AI in their concepts to provide tailored solutions in fitness and well-being experiences that encourage users to switch to healthier lifestyles.

AI empowering wellness apps for managing chronic conditions

AI’s role in the management of chronic diseases of the heart, diabetes, and asthma is particularly promising. The AI-powered apps help users track and monitor the signs and get custom treatment recommendations and advice. Take a look:

Managing diabetes: AI applications monitor blood sugar levels, suggest dietary adjustments, and remind users to take their medication timely.

AI applications monitor blood sugar levels, suggest dietary adjustments, and remind users to take their medication timely. Monitoring heart disease: AI applications can track oxygen levels, heart rate, and blood pressure, and they alert users in case of any anomaly.

AI applications can track oxygen levels, heart rate, and blood pressure, and they alert users in case of any anomaly. Managing asthma: AI applications help asthma sufferers track medication usage, symptoms, and triggers, offering insights for better disease control.

With AI’s predictive capabilities, healthcare apps have the potential to prevent complicated diseases, offering a hopeful future where further complications can be averted. These apps also inspire people to lead healthier lifestyles, reducing the need for hospital visits.

How app development companies are building a healthier tomorrow

App development companies, especially the ones involved in mobile application development in Dubai, stand tall as the key players in the rapid evolution of healthcare apps.

These companies have an advanced framework for AI technologies and can turn any basic app into predictive and intelligent systems capable of offering personalized care.

Looking forward, we can expect that the app development companies will continue to drive innovation through:

Incorporating features and innovative possibilities of AI for accurate diagnostics and better health predictions

Enhancing the seamless integration of wearable devices and IoT technologies for real-time and consistent health monitoring.

Prioritizing security and data privacy to protect user health data with strict regulations.

Expansion of telemedicine capabilities for facilitating online consultations to provide more accessible options for healthcare.

With further advancements of AI technology, healthcare apps are poised to transform even more intuitively and personalized. With app developers pushing the boundaries of possibility, the applications will not only improve user health management but also play a critical role in preventing health issues in the future—thus making wellness management more effective and smarter.

Conclusion: The Future of Healthcare Apps

AI is fundamentally revolutionizing healthcare apps by elevating them from essential health management tools to innovative platforms that offer personalized care, predictive insights, and real-time support. The applications enable a holistic approach by seamlessly integrating mental and physical wellness, empowering its users to manage their health and make data-driven decisions proactively. The advancements are setting new benchmarks in patient-centric care, efficiency, and accessibility.

In the years to come, the evolution of AI will further make wellness apps more sophisticated with capabilities like enhanced IoT integration, real-time monitoring, and predictive analytics. Leading app development companies in Dubai are working at the forefront of this innovation to ensure that these applications remain adaptable to diverse user needs, scalable, and, most importantly, secure.

As technology progresses, these applications will play a major role in advancing global healthcare outcomes.

body.title: Jean Laurenz’ multi-media show ‘DESCENDED’ takes the audience on a liberating spiritual journey
body.description: A literary giant and Laurenz’ ancestor, Lafcadio Hearn’s compelling insights on the depths of humankind and the paranormal ...
body.article_content:
University of Wisconsin-Madison assistant professor of trumpet Jean Laurenz created “ DESCENDED ,” a multimedia show of chamber music, theatrical performance and film that played at the Memorial Union Black Box theater on Oct. 19 and 20.

The show aims to take its audience on a spiritual quest to the paranormal and an otherworldly state of mind. “It’s about what happens when we, in our real physical lives, hit that membrane or cross over into that space of the beyond,” Laurenz told The Daily Cardinal. “Of the things that we'll never be able to touch, whether it's the moon or our spiritual ponderings […] We can find beauty within fear.”

Laurenz fills the room with vocals and her trumpet and is joined by professional musicians Maria Finkelheier and Greg Jukes. The three co-direct and are featured in this 55-minute show, with visuals by Xuan, the film by Four/Ten Media and music by Finkelmeier. Their work has amassed 15 nominations and awards, including from the Wisconsin Film Festival.

Laurenz’ great-great uncle and accomplished writer Lafcadio Hearn is the muse behind “DESCENDED.” A 19th century journalist, wayward traveler, teacher and meta-folk-ghost-story writer, Hearn followed his heart into the unknown.

Hearn’s metaphysical literature explores paranormal and dissonant cognitive states, and Laurenz found peace through his story as she navigated the uncertainties of a career in the arts.

“I found a lot of hope and inspiration in how one can build a beautiful life that wanders,” Laurenz said. “It gave me so much comfort just to know that I come from somebody like that.”

In their post-performance Q&A, the artists shared how liberating they feel letting go of the sheet music and focusing on gestures and the narrative arc. Rather than sticking to a rigid plan, they bring about authentic evocations, connecting to their storytelling on a deeply emotional level.

body.title: Indiana State Sanatorium's deadly history attracts interest from across the world
body.description: From tuberculosis compoud to psychiatric facility, the Indiana State Sanatorium’s eerie and deadly history continues to draw ...
body.article_content:
Since 1952, Highway 231 has served as an escape route for Lafayette area residents looking to flee the small city commotion. Heading south an hour from Lafayette, the houses and towns seem to get smaller and the communities more closely knit, guarding themselves among a changing terrain while the sugar maples multiply in number.

Catching a glance at the diverse facades and friendly faces of Mennonite settlements through the passing leaves creates a sense of wonder as to the secrets these dirt roads carry through the hills. And as these answers are kicked up in the dust behind a speeding car, a gem reveals itself around the bend.

Nestled between Bellmore and Rockville lies the grounds of what was the Indiana State Sanatorium.

Only denoted by a sign bearing two blood-red Crusader crosses, the sanatorium, and its legacy exist in local minds as a crossroads of beauty and horror, history and its mistakes. While the people of this area do not mourn its closure, its remains continue to track eyes nonetheless.

“I bought the property for the grounds,” said Gregg Larson. “And the old spooky buildings kind of came along when I bought it.”

Larson, a former engineer, acquired the sanatorium grounds during the COVID-19 pandemic. Larson and his coworker Bill Mundo became interested in the history that came with the land and quickly began to work to make it safe for exploration.

When Larson purchased the grounds, they had sat abandoned for nearly seven years, and many of the buildings were contaminated by hazardous waste and coal ash.

To mitigate this, Larson said he reached out to the Indiana Department of Environmental Management to conduct a cleaning of the site as it had originally been operated by the state.

“No matter what you’ve been told, Indiana is one of the most progressive states when it comes to cleaning up pollution … they clean it up first,” Larson said. “They spent about seven or eight million dollars cleaning up the site … they’ve done a really great job so way to go State of Indiana.”

The cleaning work revealed an extensive network of buildings and tunnels open for exploration.

Despite the clean-up, for Larson and Mundo the work continues. Along with constant maintenance, the two and their other coworkers are converting what used to be the lead doctor’s residence into a bed and breakfast.

Additionally, they are in the process of fixing the historic dairy barn to host dances for interested university groups, with the Sanatorium being situated equidistant between Purdue University, Indiana University and the University of Illinois.

Larson explained that while the Sanatorium offers bookings for exploration online, the campus still receives trespassers frequently. While Larson doesn’t remember recent trespassers from Purdue, he mentioned that a few Indiana University students had been arrested.

According to Mundo, the Sanatorium’s diverse display of architecture and facilities represents three unique phases in its over 100 years of operation.

“The Indiana State Sanatorium (was founded) in 1908. Tuberculosis was a highly contagious disease that they believed was helped by clean, fresh air,” Mundo said. “So they founded this hospital slash town in the middle of effectively nowhere on over 600 acres.”

“It was a town in the sense they had their own dairy barn, chicken coops, pig styes, slaughterhouse, cheese making, hair salon, church, school, power plant, water treatment center and everything else I can think of,” said Mundo. “A lot of the buildings (were) dormitories for people to live in ... but a lot of the hospital buildings are still around.”

After the near eradication of tuberculosis in the 1960s with the advent of more advanced antibacterial techniques, the facility was transferred to private ownership.

“It reopened after a purchase by a family of accountants from Chicago who’s father and two sons’ middle names were Lee, Alan and Bryant,” Mundo said.

This began the second era of the Sanatorium as the Lee Alan Bryant Facility. Under the group’s ownership, the facility briefly operated as a large-scale nursing facility. However, the owners encountered issues in patient numbers and were forced to innovate in order to keep their investment profitable.

“So they found a hospital up north that was a psychiatric ward that was closing and desperately looking for places to place their patients,” Mundo said.

The Lee Alan Bryant facility agreed to take all the patients from the closing facility, reopening buildings on the campus to serve as psychiatric facilities.

“The town was unhappy with that,” said Mundo, referencing the third era of the Sanatorium’s operation.

“That ran until 2011 … it closed under dubious circumstances,” Mundo said. “There were tax problems, there were malpractice suits, a lot of wrongful death suits. Their license (to practice) got pulled. The U.S. Marshals came and shut the place down and removed everybody.”

The evidence of this sudden closure remains evident in the interior of the Sanatorium buildings, left with calendars marking the day it closed. In the cafeteria, lunch trays sit out and wheelchairs remain in halls near made beds, frozen in time.

Through its three periods of operation, the Sanatorium gained a dark and occasionally tragic reputation.

“The majority (of the deaths) were tuberculosis deaths,” Mundo said. “Not sensational but significant in volume.”

Larson estimated there to be several thousand deaths that occurred on the grounds over the course of 100 years of operation.

“The deaths that happened later are much more sensational,” said Mundo, referring to the psychiatric facility. “There’s murders, suicides; a variety of different types, traumatic failures of utilities, people who escaped and died in the creek or broke into people’s houses, ran out in front of cars on the highway.”

The psychiatric building, a five-floor building, looms tall above the rest. During its operation, the facility housed mixed male and female patients on the first two floors. The third floor served as housing for female patients who could not be around men, the fourth floor for male patients who could not be around women. The fifth floor housed violent male patients, a common point of intrigue among paranormal investigators.

Mundo and Larson noted several separate incidents of suicides that occurred when patients gained access to the roof.

Near what Larson alleges may be a potter’s field, a burial ground for unknown bodies, lies the abandoned power plant. As another point of intrigue for explorers, this building and its steam tunnels were the scene of a murder-suicide.

“Personally, I’m a skeptic,” said Mundo, referring to paranormal interest in the grounds. “But the heebie jeebie factor of the big buildings is off the charts. I go in those buildings at night when I’m getting paid. When I’m not, I’m good, I am excellent.”

According to Larson, the sanatorium is booked nearly every night for exploration, a safe activity with the previous deep cleaning of the site. Many explorers come from out of state and from other nations, including well-known paranormal investigative shows from across the world.

body.title: New £6.8million attraction that kids will love opens in the UK with live shows and underground exhibitions
body.description: A NEW £6.8million state-of-the-art space attraction has opened in Nottinghamshire – and kids are going to love visiting. The ...
body.article_content:
A NEW £6.8million state-of-the-art space attraction has opened in Nottinghamshire - and kids are going to love visiting.

The Sherwood Observatory Science Discovery Centre and Planetarium in Sutton-in-Ashfield opened to the public last month.

3 Sherwood Observatory Science Discovery Centre and Planetarium in Sutton-in-Ashfield opened to the public last month Credit: JAKT Photography

3 Sherwood Observatory Science Discovery Centre and Planetarium features a cutting-edge planetarium, an education centre, an exhibition hall, a meeting room and a cafe Credit: JAKT Photography

Construction work on the new space attraction began back in 2023, with a disused underground Victorian reservoir transformed as part of the project.

Sherwood Observatory Science Discovery Centre and Planetarium features a cutting-edge planetarium, an education centre, an exhibition hall, a meeting room and a cafe.

A description on the site's website reads: "Fantastic for all ages! Learn about the wonders of the cosmos, experience the scale of the universe in our wrap-around planetarium shows, and stargaze through our observatory telescopes".

The huge dome on top of the building houses the Planetarium where screenings take place.

Inside the Planetarium, there's a 10m-high projection screen where different shows are projected and 59 seats for visitors.

Shows range from pre-recorded animations and presenter-led tours of the night sky to guest lectures and cinema shows.

Other attractions at Sherwood Observatory Science Discovery Centre and Planetarium include the Observatory Telescope, which is one of the largest public-access optical telescopes in the country.

Visitors who buy a show ticket for the Planetarium can also go to the Science Centre.

Housed inside the underground Victorian reservoir, the Science Centre is a brick building that features a mix of permanent and temporary exhibitions.

The permanent exhibition displays rocket parts that Rolls Royce donated and a display that details the history of the Victorian reservoir.

New Attractions coming to the UK

A temporary exhibition currently documents the history of human space flight.

There's also a Radio Astronomy, which is closed for refurbishment until 2025, and a cafe.

Entry tickets to shows cost £7.50 for a full-paying adult and £6 for kids.

Those visitors with show tickets can arrive one-hour before their time slot to explore the Science Centre and cafe.

Dr Steve Wallace, Chair of Sherwood Observatory and client project manager, told Building Design & Construction Commercial: "Right from the initial vision, this project has been about collaboration and teamwork.

"The new Planetarium & Science Centre has exceeded expectations and the excitement that has been generated in the area as it has taken shape has been tangible.

" We are really pleased to open our doors to visitors and show them the wonders of the universe."

Meanwhile, Cllr Jason Zadrozny, Leader of Ashfield District Council, said: "It really is spectacular, and it is something that will transform the lives of not just the people of Ashfield but also further afield."

Sherwood Observatory is a 40-minute drive from Nottingham, and it's a 70-minute drive from Birmingham.

Here are five other space attractions to visit in the UK HERE are five other space attractions for would-be astronauts to visit in the UK. National Space Centre in Leicester - This is one of the UK's leading visitor attractions dedicated to space science and astronomy, featuring interactive exhibits, the UK's largest planetarium, and the iconic Rocket Tower. Royal Observatory Greenwich in London - Established in 1675, this historic observatory offers a range of exhibits on astronomy and navigation, as well as the opportunity to stand on the Prime Meridian Line. Jodrell Bank Discovery Centre in Cheshire - Home to the famous Lovell Telescope, this centre provides visitors with interactive displays, gardens, and opportunities to learn about the universe and the workings of this significant radio telescope. Armagh Observatory and Planetarium in Northern Ireland - Founded in 1790, this observatory offers a range of educational programmes, a planetarium show, and beautiful grounds to explore. Glasgow Science Centre in Glasgow - Featuring the Planetarium, which offers immersive shows about the stars, planets, and the universe, this centre is a great place for space enthusiasts of all ages.

Meanwhile, a huge new attraction will launch in the UK next year - and it's based on an iconic 1980s video game.

And across the Atlantic, there's a new Super Nintendo World opening at the new Universal Theme Park coming to Florida next summer.

body.description: Sanofi just made its largest investment thus far in China. The company has committed just over $1 billion to build a new ...
body.article_content:
Want to stay on top of the science and politics driving biotech today? Sign up to get our biotech newsletter in your inbox.

Lots on the table today about AI-driven drug discovery, including some startups to watch in this space. Also, we’ve updated our obesity drug tracker and we talk about Gilead’s new cancer deal.

advertisement

The need-to-know this morning

Shares of Janux Therapeutics rose sharply after the company reported better-than-expected results from an early study of its experimental treatment for prostate cancer.

rose sharply after the company reported better-than-expected results from an early study of its experimental treatment for prostate cancer. Takeda is paying $200 million upfront to license an experimental drug from Keros Therapeutics in development for myelodysplastic syndrome and myelofibrosis.

is paying $200 million upfront to license an experimental drug from in development for myelodysplastic syndrome and myelofibrosis. Roivant is discontinuing the development of a drug for the lung disease sarcoidosis following negative results from a mid-stage clinical trial.

Moving forward with AI and drug discovery

The hype bubble of AI-driven drug discovery is getting a little precarious. We recently saw Insilico Medicine fall short on statistically significant efficacy with its AI-designed drug, and Recursion Pharmaceuticals showed no reportable efficacy with its own AI-discovered therapy.

AI’s true potential, Caleb Appleton of Bison Ventures opines in a new First Opinion essay, is in complementing traditional drug discovery, particularly in environments where data are plentiful enough to help answer specific biological questions.

“Improvements in efficiency will be real, but they won’t take the $3 billion it costs to develop a successful drug to $50 million anytime soon,” he writes. “How the industry reacts in the coming months and years will dictate whether we enter an AI winter.”

advertisement

Read more.

5 companies using AI to design small molecule drugs

In a related piece, STAT’s Brittany Trang this morning highlights five companies in the AI-driven drug discovery space for small molecules.

Startups like Terray Therapeutics and Isomorphic Labs are at the forefront of the field, having raised hundreds of millions of dollars to find new medicines. Interestingly, companies like Schrödinger and Iambic are distancing themselves just a touch from labels: “We don’t think of ourselves as an AI company,” said Fred Manby, chief technical officer at Iambic Therapeutics — saying instead the company integrates machine learning with automated lab data, synthetic training data generated with computational physics, and Iambic’s platform that “enables us to move so effectively in discovery.”

Read more.

Updating the obesity drug tracker. Plus, a new feature

From STAT’s Allison DeAngelis: The competition to build better obesity drugs has gotten more intense than ever.

A new quarterly update of STAT’s Obesity Drug Tracker shows there are now close to 50 obesity drugs in Phase 2 and Phase 3 clinical trials, setting the stage for a news-filled 2025.

Last week, Amgen — one of the pharma companies angling for a slice of weight loss drug sales — reported that its therapy MariTide led to an average of roughly 20% weight loss over a year. Boehringer Ingelheim has discontinued the development of an obesity drug targeting neuropeptide Y receptor type 2, while Arrowhead is moving its INHBE program into clinical trials. More startups clamored into the field this last quarter, including Kailera Therapeutics and Pep2Tango Therapeutics.

All told, the tracker is keeping tabs on roughly 150 drugs in development for weight loss and related conditions, about double the number of compounds than when STAT first published the tracker in fall 2023.

Tracking these updates is about to get even easier — you can register to get notified of updates to STAT’s data tools and industry trackers, including the Obesity Drug Tracker, Generative AI Tracker, and CRISPR Tracker.

Gilead expanding in ADCs with Tubulis

Gilead Sciences is trying harder in the antibody drug conjugate space — partnering with Germany-based Tubulis in a deal worth $20 million up front to target solid tumors. Just last month, Gilead withdrew its antibody drug conjugate Trodelvy in bladder cancer, which had been approved in 2021, after a confirmatory trial failed. Trodelvy is still available for other indications, including some advanced breast cancers, and still remains a strong seller for the company.

In the deal, Gilead said Tubulis will design a topoisomerase I inhibitor-based ADC meant to have address challenges like durability and off-target toxicity issues.

Sanofi pours $1 billion into China for insulin plant

Sanofi just made its largest investment thus far in China, committing just over $1 billion to build a new insulin manufacturing facility in Beijing. This is Sanofi’s fourth such site in China, which reflects the increasing demand for diabetes treatments for the 140 million adults there who have the disease. Sanofi’s been in China for four decades now, and the company’s plans are to integrate advanced automation, digital management, and sustainability practices into the plant.

This move comes amid challenges in China for Western pharma, FiercePharma points out, such as AstraZeneca’s compliance woes and reported layoffs at Johnson & Johnson and Merck. Pfizer, meanwhile, has its own $1 billion planned investment in the country to accelerate drug development and support local biotechs.

More reads

body.title: Build Your Android App in Days: No-Code Platform for All
body.description: Discover the best no-code platform for Android! Build your own app today—no coding skills required. Start now with YourModule ...
body.article_content:
In today’s digital age, creating mobile applications seems impossible for many businesses without programming skills. This is especially true for small businesses that may not have the resources to hire developers. However, the rise of no-code platforms has been a game-changer, allowing even those without technical experience to create functional apps for Android and other platforms.

Ready to bring your app idea to life? Head over to https://yourmodule.com/ and start building your Android app without writing a single line of code!

What Exactly is a No-Code Platform?

A no-code platform is software that enables you to design and develop a mobile application without going through the process of coding. Included are the use of drag and drop, templates and simple tools for editing your app. They are primarily intended for those who want to create something with a good appearance and optimal functionality yet do not possess the time, energy, or know-how of coding.

Mobile application development used to be limited to developers and designers, and the processes were rather complicated, time-consuming, and costly. Now with the no-code platforms, one could start designing an application with the same speed and without having to spend huge bucks hiring a developer.

Why Should You Use a No-Code Platform for Android?

If you’re wondering why you should choose a no-code platform for Android, here are a few reasons that might convince you:

Speed. With the involvement of a no-code platform, one can create an app and see results faster than traditional app development. It’s not some generational novelty that takes weeks or months for the first application to appear. You can start immediately, while in cases of templates, it can be done even faster.

Cost-Effective. Engaging a developer to create a customized app can become quite expensive. No-code platforms provide affordable ways to develop applications, thus allowing you to avoid hiring a developer. Some of these are facilitated with very cheap packages, if not free services, to enable start.

No Technical Skills Required. With no-code platforms, one does not need any expertise in coding at all. The platform is designed with an extremely user-friendly interface, providing everyone an ability to put an app together. All you need to do is perform just a couple of functions and your app is developed in the least time possible.

Highly Customizable. Although there is no coding involved, you get many options to make your app unique. Most no-code platforms give you an option of customizing the look and feel of the app according to specific needs, thus acquiring a tailor-made app without hiring a developer.

Where Can You Find the Best Android No-Code Platform?

When it comes to Android no-code app platforms, there are many choices out there. But finding the one that fits your needs can be tricky. If you’re looking for the best no-code platform for Android, there are a few things you’ll want to keep in mind:

User-Friendly. In simple terms, a no-code platform must be so intuitive that even a layperson with no prior knowledge of app development can use it with ease. Choose the platform that has a simple-user interface, where all you will need to do is drag and drop and follow the steps in the tutorials.

Features and Templates. The platform should furnish an adequate number of both templates and features to help you build your mobile application. Any type of application you want to develop should already be within the vision of this platform; business application, social application, or whatever sparkling ideas you might have in the future. The tools should allow you to essentially alter everything from the look of your app to functions that allow you to broaden its potential.

Scalability. The features, should you need the features, are designed to ensure that your application grows in popularity.

Support. There are bound to be certain issues that you will encounter, even as you use no-code platforms. This is why it is crucial to select a platform that has either an active community of users or provides adequate customer support, through live chat, email, or whatnot.

Why Choose YourModule?

The same situation is with a platform called YourModule. It is an Android no-code solution that allows anybody to create an operative application for the system without the need of learning coding. YourModule is equipped to make it easy for people to create their ideas on a low budget. It is a user-friendly platform that lets you build up your Android app with templates, and any other tools that may be necessary, and therefore, I recommend it for any person looking to build an Android app without stress from coding.

Being possibly the easiest to use, here comes YourModule, which is almost complete for a business or an individual developing an application for their business or personal use, and this platform provides you with everything you need to get started. Their customer support is available to help in case you got stuck on any issue.

Why No-Code Platforms are a Game Changer

No-code platforms are great inventions in that they give accessibility to everyone, and not just developers, who intend to develop Android applications. These platforms provide the ability to develop applications from A to Z without writing a single line of code.

If you’re in a dilemma regarding Android no-code application platforms to find suitable ones, while considering some of the best options available, YourModule is one of them. It is ideal for users that are trying to start fast, build an app without a large currency investment, and control the look and feel and functioning of the application.

Final Thoughts

No-code platforms will be the future of app development and that’s why they’re helping everyone develop their own mobile application. This is a great way to bring your own ideas to life and create mobile apps in a pretty short time with little or no coding needed.

If you want to develop an Android app without going through coding processes, I will recommend YourModule. One of the best no-code platforms that Android has, YourModule has everything you need to create an app right for you.

So what are you waiting for? Start no-code app development today and create that dream mobile app!

body.title: Fintech SaaS Startup Signzy Suffers Cyberattack: Report Fintech SaaS Startup Signzy Suffers Cyberattack: Report
body.description: Fintech SaaS startup Signzy ,which counts Gaja Capital among its backers, has reportedly confirmed a security incident ...
body.article_content:
One of Signzy’s customers PayU has confirmed that it received a written confirmation from the company

The Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT-In) is “in process of taking appropriate action with the concerned authority.”

As per multiple sources, Signzy was hit by a cyberattack last week

UPDATE | December 3, 1:15 PM

Bengaluru-based fintech SaaS startup Signzy has said it is in the process of launching a probe following an alleged security incident last week.

“We have been informed about a security incident recently and we are in the process of investigation. We value the importance of cyber security. We are taking utmost care on the same,” a Signzy spokesperson told Inc42.

Founded by Ankit Ratan, Ankur Pandey, and Arpit Ratan in 2015, Signzy provides digital onboarding solutions to banks and NBFCs via its no-code platform. The startup claims to work with more than 240 financial institutions.

Original | December 3, 11:14 AM

Fintech SaaS startup Signzy, which counts Gaja Capital, Vertex Ventures and Arkam Ventures among its backers, has reportedly confirmed a security incident.

As per TechCrunch, citing multiple sources, the Bengaluru-based startup was hit by a cyberattack last week.

The Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT-In), separately acknowledged to TechCrunch that it was aware of the incident and “in process of taking appropriate action with the concerned authority.”

Inc42has reached out to Signzy for comments on the development. The story will be updated based on the response.

One of Signzy’s customers PayU has confirmed that it received a written confirmation from the company, however, assuring that none of the payments solutions major’s data was compromised in the incident.

On the other hand, ICICI Bank mentioned that it had no exposure to the incident, the report said.

Signzy has also hired a professional agency to probe the security incident, the company’s spokesperson said.

Founded by Ankit Ratan, Ankur Pandey, and Arpit Ratan in 2015, Signzy provides digital onboarding solutions to banks and NBFCs via its no-code platform. The startup claims to work with more than 240 financial institutions.

Signzy was also recently chosen for Reserve Bank of India’s fifth cohort of the regulatory sandbox initiative. Under this initiative, companies test new products or services in a controlled regulatory environment with an opportunity to scale up their offerings, bring efficiency and devise solutions for new-age problems.

This security incident comes at a time when cyberattacks are on a rise in the country. In September, general insurance major Star Health & Allied Insurance faced a major data breach, resulting in personal data leakage of millions of its customers online.

However, later in October, the alleged hacker claimed that the insurer’s chief information security officer (CISO) sold him the data.

Similarly, in July, one of WazirX’s multisig wallets was attacked, resulting in the loss of digital assets worth over $230 Mn.

State-owned telecommunications company BSNL also suffered two data breaches within 6 months. The incident involved critical data, including international mobile subscriber identity (IMSI) numbers, SIM card information, home location register details, DP card data and even snapshots of BSNL’s SOLARIS servers.

As per a recent report by Zscaler, India now reportedly tops the list for mobile malware attacks globally, surpassing the United States and Canada.

(Note: The story has been updated to include Signzy’s comment)

body.title: Disrupting the Status Quo: Six Predictions for DevOps and QA in 2025 and Beyond
body.description: Emerge as a leader in reliability and excellence by prioritizing integration, collaboration, and forward-thinking strategies.
body.article_content:
1 Quality and Security Convergence

In 2024, we saw security start to shift left and become intertwined with product quality. In 2025, regarding quality and security as inseparable components of success will become the standard. This shift is fueled by heightened scrutiny from senior executives who recognize that flaws in either area can directly impact a company’s reputation, revenue, and long-term growth. The days of siloed teams are fading. Instead, QA, development, cybersecurity, and product teams will work in tandem—assuring fluid, cross-department engagement and collaboration, with all teams sharing roles and responsibilities to ensure holistic software integrity.

A key driver of this trend is the push to make tools and processes more integrated. Whether it’s enabling cross-team collaboration or ensuring seamless data sharing, businesses are beginning to recognize that fragmented systems slow innovation. High-quality, centralized solutions should become a core value to all companies who want to succeed in 2025. Resources to support this change should be understood as powerful investments that will aggregate value to the entire company, not only to the operational level. Companies that embrace integrated tools and cross-functional workflows will unlock faster time-to-market, elevate customer trust, and cement themselves as a strong competitor in the market.

body.title: Top 5 Cyber Security Trends for 2025
body.description: TechRepublic asked cyber experts to predict the top trends that will impact the security field in 2025. The cyber landscape ...
body.article_content:
The cyber landscape is more turbulent than ever. Microsoft recently reported a 2.75-fold increase in ransomware attempts this year, while research predicts that global cyber attacks in 2024 will surge 105% compared to 2020.

There is a dire need for more qualified cyber professionals as generative AI is lowering the barrier to entry for attacks. Unfortunately, cyber skills gaps have been reported in both the U.K. and Australia, with women making up only a quarter of the industry.

But how will we roll into next year? TechRepublic asked cyber experts to predict the top trends impacting the security field in 2025.

SEE: Number of Active Ransomware Groups Highest on Record

1. Renewed focus on third-party risk management, including the AI software supply chain

This year, headlines were dominated by the CrowdStrike incident, which disabled about 8.5 million Windows devices worldwide and caused huge disruption to emergency services, airports, law enforcement, and other critical organisations.

SEE: What is CrowdStrike? Everything You Need to Know

However, this is far from the first instance of a supply chain attack being put on the public’s radar; the MOVEit attacks from last year may also still be fresh in the mind. Due to the prevalence of these incidents, Forrester analysts predict that governments will ban certain third-party software in 2025.

Additionally, more companies are using Generative AI to code new software, which could open it up to weaknesses. AI-generated code has been known to cause outages, and security leaders are even considering banning the use of technology in software development.

For executives, this all illustrates how essential third-party risk management is to operations, leading to a new focus in 2025.

Max Shier, the chief information security officer at cyber advisory firm Optiv, told TechRepublic in an email: “Third party risk management, supply chain risk management, and increased oversight and regulatory requirements will drive the need for companies to focus on and mature their governance, risk, and compliance programs.”

Jacob Kalvo, the CEO of proxy provider Live Proxies, added: “It is expected that in 2025, organisations will likely shift toward proactive ways of assessing and monitoring supply chains. It could be leveraging zero-trust architectures that will verify at stages of access, where the companies deal with external partners.

“This shift to increased supply chain scrutiny marks a wider trend of bringing cybersecurity into general enterprise-wide risk management.”

AI software is one of the weakest links in the software supply chain

While businesses race to capitalise on generative AI solutions, the speed of their adoption has resulted in some areas of oversight when it comes to security. A study from HackerOne found that 48% of security professionals believe AI poses the most significant security risk to their organisation.

Cache Merrill, founder of software development company Zibtek, told TechRepublic by email: “As AI tools increasingly integrate into software development, we anticipate attackers targeting the software supply chain’s weakest AI-driven components. The focus will no longer be just on vetting third-party code but scrutinising AI models that may have inadvertently introduced security gaps through data poisoning or bias exploitation.

“By 2025, supply chain security will demand a whole new layer of vigilance, where even the datasets and AI models feeding into our applications are analysed for adversarial tampering. A secure supply chain won’t just be about code but curating safe and verifiable AI training sources.”

Paul Caiazzo, VP of security services at Quorum Cyber, told TechRepublic that attackers may specifically target weaker AI tools to exfiltrate sensitive data. “CISOs will struggle to secure them due to a lack of AI skills and tooling,” he added.

2. Macs will become more targeted by cybercriminals

Experts say that Macs will become even more of a target for cybercriminals in the next year. Kseniia Yamburh, malware research engineer at Moonlock, the security division of MacPaw, told TechRepublic by email: “Once considered safer, macOS now faces rising threats, particularly from stealer malware designed to collect sensitive data.

“Our research at Moonlock shows a notable spike in macOS-targeted stealer malware, with 2024 seeing 3.4 times more unique samples than 2023.”

SEE: Threat Actors Increasingly Target macOS, Report Finds

The number of macOS vulnerabilities exploited in 2023 increased by more than 30%, with attackers using infostealers, fake PDFs, fake Mac apps, legitimate Microsoft apps, and other novel techniques to breach the operating system this year. In November, several malicious macOS apps were linked to North Korea.

The growing interest in Apple devices may be due to their increasing prevalence in organisations and greater competition amongst cybercriminals in the Windows landscape.

3. Identity to shift into the jurisdiction of security teams

Security experts predict that in 2025, responsibility for identity and access management within companies will shift from IT departments to security teams. Sagie Dulce, VP of research at segmentation firm Zero Networks, said identity-based attacks are the leading cause of breaches, and this is not looking to change. As these attacks escalate, security professionals are needed to eliminate potential entry points.

Dulce told TechRepublic: “This is not new, but is a growing trend as more identities belong to services and apps — they are harder to manage and control. Most organisations are currently blind to their exposure from service accounts, privileged identities, secrets spread, third party access, and more.

“These identities are often the lowest-hanging fruits in organisations and attackers know it. As many web applications are still exposed to the internet, getting initial access via compromised credentials to a web app remains the main attack vector utilised to gain initial access.”

4. Cyber regulations will divide countries

Global cyber regulations are becoming stricter — especially with the rise in nation-state cyber attacks. As a result, legislation will focus on geopolitics and national security interests.

Vishal Gupta, CEO of security software provider Seclore, told TechRepublic in an email: “In the coming year, long raging wars and general geopolitical tensions will drive the bulk of regulations. Countries and groups of countries will create regulations to protect their own interests over deemed enemies and will prevent the broad spread of supply chains.

“This is already evident in the CHIPS act and more recent [export control law] interpretations. ‘Country over collaboration’ may well be the theme of these regulations.”

Douglas McKee, executive director of Threat Research at security firm SonicWall, added that it will become increasingly difficult to detect the origins of attacks because “the line between state and criminal operations will continue to blur further.”

SEE: Tenable: Cyber Security Pros Should Worry About State-Sponsored Cyber Attacks

As a result, decision-makers should strengthen international collaboration rather than create more division. McKee told TechRepublic in an email: “Governments and private organisations must adapt to this evolving threat landscape, focusing more on proactive intelligence sharing and threat-hunting to disrupt collaborative efforts before they impact critical sectors.”

Critical national infrastructure will fall behind in compliance

Critical national infrastructure, such as transport, telecommunications companies, and data centres, is a key target for attackers because it can lead to widespread disruption. A recent report from Malwarebytes found that the services industry is the worst affected by ransomware, accounting for almost a quarter of global attacks.

SEE: 80% of Critical National Infrastructure Companies Experienced an Email Security Breach in Last Year

According to Christian Borst, EMEA CTO at security firm Vectra AI, attacks on CNI will surge in 2025, partly because these firms are not keeping up with regulations. These include NIS2, which aims to establish a consistent, minimum cybersecurity baseline across all E.U. member states.

Borst told TechRepublic in an email: “Regulators aren’t asking the world, but CNI firms are already struggling to stick to the timelines set out by regulators and get their houses in order, as we’re already seeing E.U. member states who are lagging behind on NIS2 implementation.

“Threat actors will be well aware of lagging compliance, so will concentrate efforts on targeting critical infrastructure before the security gaps are closed.”

5. Specific employees targeted via social media and AI

At the start of the year, a finance worker in Hong Kong paid out $25 million to hackers that used AI and publicly available video content to impersonate the chief financial officer. The hackers mimicked the executive’s voice during phone calls to authorise the transfer.

Experts predict that this behaviour will continue into 2025. According to Garner, AI-enhanced malicious attacks were the top emerging business risk throughout the year’s first three quarters.

The number of business email compromise attacks detected by security firm Vipre in the second quarter was 20% higher than the same period in 2023, and two-fifths of them were generated by AI. The top targets were CEOs, followed by HR and IT personnel.

Darius Belejevas, head of data privacy platform Incogni, told TechRepublic: “An ever-increasing number of data breaches are now the result of criminals actively targeting specific employees, in some cases armed with personal information they have managed to source on that individual. Unfortunately not enough people realise they are being targeted because of where they work.”
